references.N87FOE01USGP: Foerster, K. S. 1987. The distribution and breeding biology of the Black Swift Cypseloides niger in southern California. Master's Thesis. California State Univ. Long Beach, CA.
references.B90CAM04USGP: Campbell, R. W., N. K. Dawe, I. McTaggart-Cowan, J. M. Cooper, G. W. Kaiser, and M. C. E. McNall. 1990. The birds of British Columbia, Vol. 2: diurnal birds of prey through woodpeckers. R. Br. Columbia Mus. Victoria.
references.B02LOW01USGP: Lowther, Peter E. and Charles T. Collins. 2002. Black Swift (Cypseloides niger), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/676.
references.A61KNO01USGP: Knorr, O. A. 1961. The geographical and ecological distribution of the Black Swift in Colorado. Wilson Bull. 73:155-170.
references.B94SMA01USGP: Small, A. 1994. California birds: their status and distribution. Ibis Publ. Co. Vista, CA.

habitat_description:
All Regions:
Nests on ledges or shallow caves in steep rock faces and canyons, usually near or behind waterfalls, and in sea caves. Ranges widely to forage over both forest and open areas in montane habitats (Subtropical and Temperate zones; Am. Ornithol. Union 1998). In British Columbia, found from 0 to 2,600 m (Campbell et al. 1990); in California, from 0 to 2,300 m (Small 1994).
Most documented nesting sites are associated with sheer cliffs and waterfalls (Lowther and Collins, 2002). This species is not considered an abundant summer resident. May use inland sites near or behind waterfalls in mountains. Specialize in foraging on nuptial flight swarms of fat-rich winged reproductive ants.  May also feed on caddisflies, mayflies, flesh flies, and hymenopterans.  Species is critically imperiled in NM and UT(NatureServe). The appearance of this species coincides with prominent weather conditions such as barometric pressure, wind direction, and precipitation.  As of 1910: The black swift breeds from southern British Columbia and southern Colorado to central Mexico; assumed to winter in southern Mexico, but not known; needs 5 characteristics for nesting sites: water, high relief, inaccessibility, darkness, and unobstructed flyways (Knorr, 1961).
